title: Volgare - by Stephen Farrell
content:
Hello folks,   
I have been asked to track down a typeface called Volgare. I've done some research on the net and found out it was developed by Stephen Farrell from Slip Studios. Most of his fonts are licenced through [T-26] but not this one. Does anyone know the font and if it is commercially available?
author: skyrocket

comments.content:
I tried, but couldn't track it down either.   
There is nothing so annoying as seeing a typeface   
lauded in the annuals and then not being able to obtain it.   
dhall

Isn't that "Volgare Project" CD for sale anywhere?   
And I'm sure there's a way to track down an email for Farrell - maybe through Emigre.   
   
hhp

Paul, I am a HUGE fan of Volgare. There is little information about it on the web. Here is the best and only page that describes Volgare: [http://www.altx.com/ebr/ads/ebr6/farrell/page3.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115190425/http:/www.altx.com/ebr/ads/ebr6/farrell/page3.htm) (it's a pain in the  to navigate though).   
   
Volgare took Stephen 4 years to make and you can tell in its detailed construction. All the information I know about it is in that link above, so I encourage you to read that. If you want a copy of the font you have to call Stephen and ask him to send you a CD with the font, it costs $75. It is well worth the price.   
   
He is also mentioned in this article on Design Observer [http://www.designobserver.com/archives/000021.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115190425/http:/www.designobserver.com/archives/000021.html)   
   
As mentioned there, Volgare was on display at the Cooper Hewitt's original design triennial [http://ndm.si.edu/triennial/animation.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115190425/http:/ndm.si.edu/triennial/animation.html)

[http://www.altx.com/ebr/ads/ebr6/farrell/orderfrm.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115190425/http:/www.altx.com/ebr/ads/ebr6/farrell/orderfrm.htm) -- I just noticed that Armin posted linkage to the same thread. Oh well.

FYI: Stephen Farrell teaches at The School of the Art Institute of Chicago, contact can be made with the Visual Communication Dept. I'm sure Volage is still available for sale.

[http://www.saic.edu/gallery/saic\_profile\_faculty.php?type=Faculty&alpha=...](http://web.archive.org/web/20141115190425/http:/www.saic.edu/gallery/saic_profile_faculty.php?type=Faculty&alpha=F&album=467 "http://www.saic.edu/gallery/saic\_profile\_faculty.php?type=Faculty&alpha=F&album=467")

I like a lot the way Volgare seems assembled.  
I had the opportunity to see how difficult it is to keep a manuscript handwriting "natural", without added stylizations when I attempted a similar thing a few years ago.
